author: By Everdeen Mason
title: Pampered Pets
description: Sarah Sinclair and Amie Walker have put together a charming Tuesday crossword with a lot of breadth.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Super PAC Tied to Elon Musk Is Being Guided by Ex-DeSantis Aides
description: The group, America PAC, which is funded by allies of Elon Musk, is said to be steered by two well-known Republican operatives who worked on behalf of Ron DeSantis’s presidential bid.
content: Two Republican operatives who played senior roles helping the presidential campaign of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida have taken on leadership roles in a new pro-Trump super PAC that could spend tens of millions of dollars in the presidential race and has ties to Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney, Charlie Smart and Christine Zhang
title: Democratic Delegates See Harris as the Strongest Candidate Against Trump
description: With Vice President Kamala Harris locking up support, interviews with Democratic National Committee delegates indicated there was no consensus over whom she should pick as a running mate.
content: Delegates to the Democratic National Convention support the party moving forward swiftly to nominate Kamala Harris as their presidential candidate, rather than going through a prolonged and potentially divisive debate, according to interviews conducted by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: In Wilmington, They Like ‘Delaware Joe.’ But They’re Glad He Quit.
description: Support is strong for President Biden in his home city. But, as one local put it, “You got to know when to hold ’em, know when to fold ’em.”
content: As President Biden met with confidants last week to discuss whether he should end his re-election campaign, John Flaherty, a retired government employee, was seated in a booth at Angelo’s Luncheonette in Wilmington, Del., the small city that has been Mr. Biden’s political home base for more than 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Alphabet Reports 29% Jump in Profit as A.I. Efforts Begin to Pay Off
description: Google’s parent company narrowly topped revenue and profit expectations, driven by its search engine and cloud unit, and it said A.I. investments were “driving new growth.”
content: Google faced a setback on Monday when the cybersecurity start-up Wiz rejected its $23 billion acquisition offer, a deal that could have given momentum to its cloud-computing operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Kate Kelly
title: Secret Service Director Resigns After Trump Assassination Attempt
description: Kimberly A. Cheatle gave up her post Tuesday after security failures that allowed a gunman to shoot at former President Donald J. Trump at an open-air rally.
content: The director of the Secret Service, Kimberly A. Cheatle, resigned on Tuesday, after security failures surrounding the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump and calls for her to step down from lawmakers in both parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Mattel Unveils Blind Barbie
description: A second new doll, a Black Barbie with Down syndrome, is part of the toymaker’s effort to be more inclusive.
content: In the decades since Barbie debuted in 1959, the doll’s plastic perfections have generated criticism for their promotion of unrealistic beauty standards. In response, Mattel has tried to create versions that are more representative of a broader range of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: U.A.W. Holds Off on Endorsing Harris
description: Unlike other prominent unions, the auto workers are taking their time to ensure that the vice president is aligned with them on key policy questions.
content: A succession of unions and labor federations this week have endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination, but one prominent group has stood out for its relative silence: the United Automobile Workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 8 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: Listen to songs by Clairo, Dawn Richard and Sturgill Simpson plus more.
content: These days I’ve really been enjoying “Charm,” the recently released third album from the 25-year-old singer-songwriter Clairo. I’ve been following Clairo’s music for some time now, and the ambling path she’s taken to finding her own unique voice has been refreshing — perhaps even anachronistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman and Christina Goldbaum
title: When Pakistan Tightened a Border, Thousands of Lives Were Upended
description: Traders in Chaman have done business in Afghanistan for generations, but that stopped when officials made it much harder to cross.
content: For most of Abdul Manan’s life, the border dividing Afghanistan and Pakistan was little more than a line on a map. Like generations of men before him, Mr. Manan, 55, commuted every day from his mud-brick home on the Pakistan side to the wheat field his family had cultivated for decades in Afghanistan. His four sons crossed the border with him, transporting electronics and groceries from markets on one side to homes on the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu Seeks Support in U.S. Visit, but Will Find a Nation Distracted
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is to meet President Biden and address Congress this week, swapping one political maelstrom at home for another in Washington.
content: With his visit to Washington this week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will step away from one political maelstrom and into another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Returns to a Vastly Different Presidency With Six Months to Go
description: Now a lame duck, the president plans to address the nation on Wednesday night to discuss “what lies ahead.” But it could be a frustrating period.
content: Even though he is no longer a candidate for re-election, President Biden insists that he is “not going anywhere,” and it is true that his lease on the White House has another six months, or roughly an eighth of his entire term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Between Attacks on Electric Cars, Trump Says They’re ‘Incredible’
description: The former president’s comments on E.V.s have shifted since he has grown more friendly with Elon Musk, the billionaire head of Tesla.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has spent years ridiculing electric vehicles, saying they don’t go far, are too expensive and are made in China. He has promised to end federal support for electric vehicles, a central feature of President Biden’s strategy to cut the carbon dioxide that is heating the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Accuses Biden-Harris Administration of Failing to ‘Properly Protect Me’
description: The former president’s comments suggest that he will more aggressively turn the assassination attempt into a political cudgel.
content: After initially praising the Secret Service following the near-miss assassination attempt this month, former President Donald J. Trump for the first time blamed his political rivals, President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris, for failing to protect him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly McMasters
title: Adultery, a Corpse Eaten by Alligators and a $1 Million Insurance Payout
description: A true-crime case that could only happen in Florida is at the heart of Mikita Brottman’s “Guilty Creatures.”
content: Were Mikita Brottman’s “Guilty Creatures” a work of fiction, the plot would be deemed clichéd: an affair, a missing body presumed eaten by alligators, a million-dollar life insurance payout and a beautiful widow who quickly finds love in the arms of her dead husband’s newly divorced best friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Are You Planning to Leave the U.S. if the Election Doesn’t Go Your Way? We’d Like to Hear From You.
description: As the 2024 election season heats up, some Americans are considering leaving the country. We want to hear about their plans and perspective.
content: As national politics reach a fever pitch, some Americans are contemplating leaving the country depending on the outcome of the 2024 election. Some are already living abroad —  in part, the result of  what they see as an increasingly toxic political, social and cultural environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Matthew Barney’s Time Has Come Again
description: Misunderstood for decades, the sculptor and filmmaker is pushing ceramic to its limits. He’s dancing. He’s making the best work of his career.
content: Something curious happened to Matthew Barney over the last 15 years: He became underrated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. Will Restart Cruise Taxi Operations
description: General Motors said the self-driving division’s cars will run in Dallas, Houston and Phoenix after an accident last year. Human drivers will supervise the cars.
content: General Motors said on Tuesday that its Cruise driverless-taxi division has restarted test operations in three Sun Belt cities, using self-driving cars with human safety drivers who will monitor the vehicles and intervene if needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Lezak
title: This Dirty Industry Is Better Off Operating in America
description: The ethical thing to do is to bring mining back and hold it to the highest sustainability standards.
content: Seventy years ago, the United States was the world’s leading producer of fluorite, a brilliantly multicolored mineral essential to industries such as steel. But the last American fluorite mine closed nearly 30 years ago, unable to compete with cheaper operations in places like Mongolia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate LoPresti, John White, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez and Rhonda Garelick
title: Dr. Ruth Talked About Sex Like No One Else Could
description: How the sex therapist disarmed her audience.
content: For decades, Dr. Ruth Westheimer was the person to call if you had a question about sex. On her talk shows and late-night television appearances, she fielded inquiries about every facet of human sexuality. In the wake of Dr. Ruth’s death at age 96, the writer Rhonda Garelick reflects on the therapist’s legacy and her remarkable ability to put people at ease. “Dr. Ruth was able to say words that no one else could say, talk about topics that no one else could talk about,” Garelick says. “She made graphic sex talk seem like teatime ladies’ chat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Qasim Nauman
title: Canada Evacuates Jasper National Park as Wildfires Burn in Alberta
description: Large blazes in the province have led to the evacuation of thousands of people.
content: A raging wildfire forced the evacuation late Monday of Jasper National Park in Western Canada, where thousands of people have fled their homes in the past four days because of large blazes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Walter Shapiro, Political Columnist With a Contrarian Streak, Dies at 77
description: He brought to his writing a sharp sense of humor, honed in stand-up comedy clubs, and never pulled punches even though he was an unabashed Democrat.
content: Walter Shapiro, a canny, penetrating and often contrarian political columnist whose career included stints as a presidential speechwriter, stand-up comic, professor, author and, as a recent college graduate, congressional candidate, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 23, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 23, 2024.
content: An article on Sunday about a dispute over stray cattle that started a broader conflict in an upstate New York town misidentified the charge that one of Tracy Murphy’s lawyers was convicted of in a case involving stolen ducks. The lawyer, Wayne Hsiung, was convicted of felony conspiracy to commit trespass, not the theft of the ducks. It also misstated the consequences of Mr. Hsiung’s conviction. His law license was placed on interim suspension; he has not been disbarred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Is Coqodaq a Fancy Fried-Chicken Joint or the End of the World?
description: With drumsticks in buckets and hundreds of Champagnes, Coqodaq leans into the city’s weird, giddy, and-the-band-played-on mood.
content: Coqodaq is a six-month-old, 8,000-square-foot restaurant on East 22nd Street that may remind you, at various points in the evening, of an airplane hangar, a church, a roller disco, a Las Vegas casino and a Quonset hut. At times it seems like the first in a new species of restaurant, and at others it seems like the end of civilization. It may be the most interesting place to open in Manhattan since the start of pandemic, in part because it can be so many things at once without being especially good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Judge Refuses to Block F.T.C.’s Noncompete Ban as Lawsuits Play Out
description: A federal judge in Pennsylvania denied a request to delay the rule, siding with the agency and diverging from another court’s decision this month.
content: A federal judge in Pennsylvania on Tuesday declined to block the Federal Trade Commission’s ban on noncompete agreements, diverging from another judge’s recent finding that the agency’s move was on shaky legal ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Wednesday Briefing: Democrats Unite Behind Kamala Harris
description: Plus, the head of the Secret Service resigns.
content: The top two Democrats in Congress endorsed Kamala Harris as their party’s presidential candidate yesterday, after she received commitments from enough delegates to secure the nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Warner Bros. Discovery Makes Matching Offer in Bid to Keep N.B.A. Rights
description: The company, a longtime broadcaster of N.B.A. games, is trying to keep the lucrative broadcast rights as the league negotiates a new contract.
content: Warner Bros. Discovery said on Monday that it had matched a rival offer to air N.B.A. games, a move aimed at allowing the company to keep the lucrative broadcast rights it has held for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: How Fit Are You? Test Yourself to Find Out.
description: There are many ways to gauge how strong and healthy you are. Here are some of our favorites.
content: Tests can tell you a lot about yourself — like whether you have Covid or what kind of friend you are. And some of them can give you an idea of your fitness level, by showing you where you need to improve and allowing you to track your progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather and Alex Marshall
title: Caught Repeatedly Whipping a Horse, Top British Rider Is Out of the Olympics
description: “There is no excuse,” Charlotte Dujardin, a three-time gold medalist, said of her actions captured on video. “I am deeply ashamed and should have set a better example in that moment.”
content: Charlotte Dujardin, one of the world’s most renowned dressage riders, will not compete at the 2024 Olympic Games in Paris after video footage emerged showing the British athlete repeatedly whipping a horse during a training session.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: In Georgia’s Depressed Heartland, Pining for the Soviet Past
description: While most Georgians support closer integration with Western Europe, many people in industrial areas that collapsed along with Communism in the 1990s express nostalgia for the old Soviet prosperity.
content: The town of Kazreti, nestled in the picturesque mountains of Georgia near the border with Armenia, once boasted a cinema, a bank, musical fountains, two schools and a kindergarten. Dance ensembles and volleyball teams from across the Soviet Union would come to perform and compete, and central heating and electricity were free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Hisako Ueno
title: Noriko Ohara, Who Gave Voice to a Beloved Anime Character, Dies at 88
description: She starred in “Doraemon” and other animated shows watched by nearly every child in Japan, and her voice became widely recognized.
content: Noriko Ohara, the Japanese voice actress who for decades played the role of Nobita on the beloved animated children’s show “Doraemon,” giving life to a main character on one of the country’s longest-running television shows, has died. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: The Conductor Who Bent Music History to His Will
description: Serge Koussevitzky, a prolific commissioner born 150 years ago, made his mark not only on the Boston Symphony Orchestra, but also on American music.
content: There is a passage in Serge Koussevitzky’s final recording of Tchaikovsky’s Fourth Symphony that some listeners might hear in horror, but others with a degree of awe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: What Polling Tells Us About a Kamala Harris Candidacy
description: Sorting out whether she’s an upgrade for Democrats.
content: There’s rarely a perfect time to be a pollster, but on Sunday afternoon, as my latest national survey of voters was wrapping up, President Biden announced that he was withdrawing from the 2024 race and endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Harris Campaign Begins
description: The Democratic Party’s biggest weaknesses — and how they offer Kamala Harris an opportunity.
content: Kamala Harris has an opportunity that would not have been available to President Biden if he’d been the Democratic nominee. She can reintroduce herself to voters in ways that address their biggest complaints about Biden’s record and the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Rodham Clinton
title: Hillary Clinton: How Kamala Harris Can Win and Make History
description: I’ve been called a witch, a “nasty woman” and much worse. Harris will face unique additional challenges. But we shouldn’t be afraid.
content: History has its eye on us. President Biden’s decision to end his campaign was as pure an act of patriotism as I have seen in my lifetime. It should also be a call to action to the rest of us to continue his fight for the soul of our nation. The next 15 weeks will be like nothing this country has ever experienced politically, but have no doubt: This is a race Democrats can and must win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Can Kamala Harris Sell ‘Bidenomics’?
description: Much of President Biden’s agenda polls well, but voters roundly dislike his handling of the economy. That’s a campaign challenge for his vice president, as she mounts a presidential bid.
content: Kamala Harris hits the campaign trail after President Biden exits. Follow live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google’s $23 Billion Plan to Buy Cybersecurity Start-Up Wiz Falls Apart
description: Wiz’s chief executive said the company walked away from a “humbling offer” and would pursue an initial public offering instead.
content: Last week, it looked like Google was poised to snap up the cybersecurity start-up Wiz for $23 billion, in what would have been its largest acquisition ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: ‘A Voice Can Change You’: The Week 5 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
description: In her 90-second video, Annie Ma, 14, explains how an essay by the singer Dessa hit home for her.
content: For 15 years, our Summer Reading Contest has been inviting teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This year, for the first time, students can submit either written comments or 90-second video responses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Says He Is Willing to Debate Harris Multiple Times
description: But for the second time since President Biden dropped out of the race, he indicated he didn’t want the debate to be held by ABC News.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Tuesday that he would “absolutely” be willing to debate Vice President Kamala Harris, who has already clinched commitments from enough delegates to become the Democratic presidential nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Triumphant Comeback of the Kamala Harris Meme
description: The same unflattering supercuts and Photoshop jobs once used to denigrate Harris have now been flipped into celebratory artifacts of her candidacy.
content: Kamala Harris is a highly memeable presidential candidate. She dances in a loose and enthusiastic manner. She has an idiosyncratic speaking style. She laughs easily, including at herself. This has not always worked in her favor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are Democrats Right to Unite Around Kamala Harris?
description: The Democratic Party has a chance to organize for victory.
content: The transcript of this audio essay has been edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Sewage Spill Temporarily Closes Two Los Angeles Beaches
description: An estimated 15,000 gallons of sewage spilled into a creek this weekend, closing Venice and Dockweiler State Beaches, officials said. But on Tuesday morning, locals stuck to their beach routines.
content: Two Los Angeles-area beaches were shut down for 48 hours after thousands of gallons of sewage spilled into a creek — but that did not seem to bother the crowd of dog walkers, runners, yogis and surfers enjoying the beach early on Tuesday before the day’s heat set in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Time Bandits’ Review: A Flatter Adventure
description: An adaptation of the 1981 film on Apple TV+ gives us time-traveling bandits of greater height and lesser amusement.
content: When the bandits of the title burst into the bedroom of Kevin, an 11-year-old history buff, in the new Apple TV+ series “Time Bandits,” among the first things you are likely to notice is: no dwarfs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: How Democrats Learned to Love the Smoke-Filled Room Again
description: It’s because they want to win.
content: Good evening. It took less than two days for Vice President Kamala Harris to secure commitments from enough delegates to capture the Democratic presidential nomination, so my colleague Charles Homans is here to tell us how a party that spent much of the past year divided fell in line. Then, I’m brat — I mean, back — with a look at that meme. — Jess Bidgood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Deadpool & Wolverine’ Review: Nothing Ever Ends
description: The wisecracking semi-hero is back, but now he’s part of a bigger universe.
content: “Disney’s so stupid,” Deadpool declares trollishly at the beginning of “Deadpool & Wolverine.” It’s the sort of jab — in this case, at the studio distributing the film we’re watching — that we’ve grown used to from this dude, a potty-mouthed exterminator in a face-obscuring suit vaguely reminiscent of Spider-Man. Not quite a hero, not quite anything else, Deadpool is an answer to the conflicted but upstanding superheroes of 21st-century Hollywood. He kills messily, he makes a lot of inappropriate jokes and, in an industry that practically decrees a profit-boosting PG-13 rating, his movies are always rated R.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Dillon
title: When It Comes to a Bad Marriage, Whose Account Can You Trust?
description: The aggrieved wife who narrates Sarah Manguso’s novel “Liars” may or may not be a reliable source about her monster of a husband.
content: The cardinal mystery in Sarah Manguso’s second novel (she has also published several books of poetry, short stories and nonfiction) goes unplumbed until halfway through, when a neighbor is aghast at the narrator’s marital predicament: “Why are you still with him?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: George Clooney Endorses Kamala Harris, Says Biden Is ‘Saving Democracy’
description: In a statement, the actor and Democratic donor praised the president for stepping aside and vowed to do “whatever we can” to support Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign.
content: Actor and Democratic fund-raiser George Clooney endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential candidacy on Tuesday morning and thanked President Biden for deciding not to seek re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamilton Cain
title: An Undocumented Immigrant Admitted to the Elite World of Harvard
description: Karla Cornejo Villavicencio’s fiction debut, “Catalina,” brings readers into the life and struggles of a blue-collar brainiac from Ecuador.
content: Unlike this nation’s ailing body politic, our caste system is alive and robust, as the journalist Isabel Wilkerson argues. Nowhere is that more apparent than amid the couture quadrangles and clock towers of elite universities. For Catalina Ituralde, the winsome narrator of Karla Cornejo Villavicencio’s sparkling fiction debut, “Catalina,” a scholarship to Harvard thrusts her to the apex of that system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: When It Comes to Food and Politics, Kamala Harris Is Riffing on the Recipe
description: From giving turkey-roasting advice to making dosa with Mindy Kaling, Ms. Harris has leaned into cooking in a way no other candidate has.
content: Only a handful of presidents have had a keen interest in cooking. Dwight Eisenhower popularized a method for grilling steaks directly on the coals. Jimmy Carter considered himself a good country cook. Abraham Lincoln was known to put on an apron.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Starting 15-Week Dash, Harris Presses Case
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 23, 2024.
content: “One day down. 105 to go.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Ben Protess
title: Trump Appeals $454 Million Fraud Judgment, Saying It Was Excessive
description: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump challenged the judgment handed down by Justice Arthur F. Engoron, who found that Mr. Trump had conspired to manipulate his net worth to receive favorable terms on loans.
content: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump filed an appeal on Monday evening seeking to dismiss or drastically reduce the $454 million judgment levied against him this year in a New York civil fraud case, the latest maneuver in the former president’s multiple legal battles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Unions tell the Biden administration to stop sending military aid to Israel.
description: Several unions with millions of members demanded that the president secure a cease-fire in Gaza.
content: A group of unions representing millions of workers sent a letter on Tuesday to the White House demanding a cease-fire in the war in Gaza and that the United States stop sending military aid to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: An Olympian’s Awkward Packing List: Toothbrush? Check. Rifle? Check.
description: For members of the U.S. shooting team, competitions may be the easy part. Just getting to them takes steely nerves and careful planning.
content: Olympic shooters have time-tested mental exercises they use to get through some of the most stressful moments of their careers: They exhale deeply to steady their nerves. They assess the targets ahead of them. They trust in the preparation that got them there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Frustrated Californians May Be Ready for a Tougher Approach to Crime
description: Shoplifting and fentanyl use have tested the patience of California voters, who will decide in November whether to impose stricter laws that would lead to more incarceration.
content: Deodorant, shampoo and underwear are all under lock and key in many stores in California. Retail clerks are often told to ignore shoplifters, after a handful of store employees who confronted thieves were assaulted or killed. Video clips of smash-and-grab crews snatching armloads of merchandise have gone viral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Dean Phillips, Biden’s Withdrawal Offers ‘Unfulfilling’ Vindication
description: The congressman from Minnesota waged a quixotic challenge in the Democratic primaries, warning that the president was too old to win. No one paid attention then. They are now.
content: For Dean Phillips, the modern Cassandra of American politics, this I-told-you-so moment brings no joy. A little vindication, yes. Sadness, too, and sympathy for a man who gave his life to public service and deserved a better finale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron Rejects French Left’s Pick for Prime Minister
description: The left-wing parties stopped quarreling and tapped a little-known civil servant for the job. But President Emmanuel Macron said he would not appoint anyone until after the Paris Summer Olympics.
content: A coalition of France’s left-wing parties on Tuesday tapped a little-known civil servant to be prime minister, unexpectedly ending weeks of bickering after snap parliamentary elections plunged the country into political gridlock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Reid J. Epstein, Eric Krupke, Diana Nguyen, Clare Toeniskoetter, Lynsea Garrison, Mooj Zadie, Patricia Willens, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: The New Hope, and New Worry, of Kamala Harris
description: The vice president has no real competition for the Democratic nomination, despite polling that shows weaknesses in her candidacy.
content: As Democrat after Democrat races to anoint Vice President Kamala Harris as their party’s presidential candidate, it has become clear that she will face no real challenge for the nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Caught in the CrowdStrike Outage? Here’s How to Get Compensated.
description: Air travelers paying for last-minute lodging and other expenses are entitled to be reimbursed if their flight was impacted by an event in the airline’s control, like the CrowdStrike failure. Here’s how to get your money back.
content: The global software outage last week caused thousands of travelers flying in the United States and internationally to have their flights delayed, canceled or both. In the days that followed, some airlines were trying to reboot critical computer systems affected by the outage, with many of their passengers still stranded at airports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxanna Asgarian
title: How QAnon Rips Families Apart
description: In “The Quiet Damage,” Jesselyn Cook traces the effects of the conspiracy theory on the spouses, children and siblings of believers.
content: The percentage of Americans who believe in conspiracy theories may not actually be increasing — one recent study suggests the figure has been largely stable, if disturbingly high, over time — but for anyone active on social media during the past few years, it has certainly seemed that way. The pandemic unleashed a perfect storm of conditions: Mass Covid lockdowns fueled mistrust in the government and fears about the vaccine. Americans were stuck at home endlessly scrolling, and social media algorithms were priming more and more people to travel further down the dark reaches of the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla’s Profit Fell 45% in the Second Quarter on Weak E.V. Sales
description: The company led by Elon Musk is selling fewer electric cars, and its big bets on driverless taxis and artificial intelligence could take many years to pay off.
content: Tesla on Tuesday reported a 45 percent drop in profit in the three-month period between April and June, a result of the electric car company’s sluggish sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘He Liked to Give Me Gifts’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: It was the day my wife and I were going to meet, for the first time, the man who held parts of our daughter, who died at 16, inside him: her pancreas and one kidney. As we walked from our front door to the car, a hawk flew toward us and settled in the nearest tree. Maybe 30 feet away? The hawk just sat silently watching. In 15 years in our house, we had never seen a hawk in the yard. We waited, staring, and the hawk stared back. “Hello, Anna,” my wife said. The man is doing very well. — Stephen Burns
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Hurtes
title: Art Student Pulls Off a (Very Brief) Coin Heist at the British Museum
description: The artist aimed to use sleight of hand to point to what he described as the museum’s problematic legacy of colonial-era acquisitions.
content: A Brazilian artist strolled into the British Museum last month and approached a table where visitors are allowed to interact with historic objects. After handling a 17th-century British coin for a moment, he seemingly returned it and moved on, like thousands of other visitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Staples
title: Biden Should Have Treated Harris as a Future President
description: She was not set up for success.
content: In just three and a half weeks, Kamala Harris has moved from the shadows to the forefront of the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Alcoba
title: Writing Helped Her Realize She Was a Woman. It Also Made Her Famous.
description: Camila Sosa Villada, an Argentine transgender author, first inhabited a female voice in stories she wrote as a child. Now her novels are translated in more than 20 languages and being adapted for the screen.
content: Before Camila Sosa Villada transitioned and stepped out into the world as a woman, she wrote as one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: An Unbending Leader’s Crackdown Rains Carnage on Bangladesh
description: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina’s response to protests has left at least 150 people dead and created the biggest challenge yet to her grip on power.
content: For those watching from outside, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh presents a compelling story. She is among the world’s longest-serving female heads of government, a secular Muslim in colorful saris who has fought Islamic militancy, lifted millions out of poverty and deftly kept both India and China at her side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang, Jin Yu Young and John Yoon
title: Founder of South Korean Tech Giant Arrested Over K-Pop Deal
description: Kim Beom-su, the billionaire behind Kakao, was taken into custody on allegations of stock manipulation during a bidding war over a K-pop agency.
content: The billionaire founder of the South Korean technology giant Kakao, Kim Beom-su, was arrested on Tuesday over allegations of stock price manipulation related to the company’s investment in one of the country’s largest K-pop agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Kamala Harris’s first campaign appearance.
content: At her campaign headquarters in Delaware, Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a spirited and aggressive assault on Donald Trump, saying her law enforcement background would help her defeat a rival who is a convicted criminal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Attacking Kamala Harris for Not Having Kids Will Backfire
description: Being a parent doesn’t make you a better politician.
content: On Sunday, almost immediately after prominent Democrats started endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris for president, attacks from the political right started pouring in. Will Chamberlain, a conservative lawyer who worked on Ron DeSantis’s presidential campaign, posted on X that Harris “shouldn’t be President” because she doesn’t have biological children; “becoming a step-parent to older teenagers doesn’t count,” he wrote, adding that “The concerns of parents and families will always be abstract to her” because she doesn’t have “skin in the game, a stake in the future, and the lived experience of raising children.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer, Michael C. Bender and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: JD Vance Hits the Money Circuit After Joining Trump’s Ticket
description: Presidential running mates are always responsible for bringing in cash, but Mr. Vance, who has old ties to Silicon Valley, appears to be leaning into the role heavily.
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio is moving aggressively to raise money for the Republican presidential ticket, making fund-raising one of his earliest priorities as he seeks to convert his donor relationships into cash as the running mate for former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Kumerra Gemechu
title: Two Landslides Kill 229 People in Ethiopia
description: A waterlogged hillside above a village gave way, burying several houses in mud. Neighbors and rescue workers who had rushed to help were hit by a second slide.
content: At least 229 people were killed in southwestern Ethiopia on Monday after a landslide flattened several houses in a village following days of heavy rain, and neighbors who rushed to dig out those buried under the mud were hit with a second landslide about an hour later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Congress Calls for Tech Outage Hearing to Grill CrowdStrike C.E.O.
description: The House Homeland Security Committee called on the chief executive of the cybersecurity firm to testify on the disruption.
content: A Congressional committee called on the chief executive of CrowdStrike to testify at a hearing about its role in a tech outage that roiled the global economy, in one of the first attempts to hold the cybersecurity company responsible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Tracey Tully
title: Menendez Will Resign From Senate, Avoiding an Ugly, Intraparty Battle
description: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey was facing a possible expulsion vote after his conviction on federal corruption charges last week.
content: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey announced on Tuesday that he would resign from Congress effective in late August, bowing to intense pressure from Democratic colleagues who had pushed him to step down or face an expulsion vote after his conviction in a vast international bribery scheme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Immigration Is Great for Jobs, Actually
description: Why the economic impact of immigration is positive.
content: On the eve of the 2020 election Donald Trump, in a post on the platform formerly known as Twitter, told voters that “This election is a choice between a TRUMP RECOVERY or a BIDEN DEPRESSION.” Not quite. Since President Biden took office, the United States has gained 15.7 million jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Hear Us Out: Angel Hair Pasta
description: Dan Pelosi’s new recipe tosses the strands with olive oil, butter, garlic, herbs and blistered cherry tomatoes for a perfect pan of pasta.
content: My excellent editor, Mia Leimkuhler, recently asked me to reconsider angel hair pasta and — while I was revisiting the 1990s — watch the movie “Twister,” which came out in 1996 and has a new sequel, “Twisters.” Mia, I’ve completed this assignment. Here goes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Dzombak
title: Secrets Emerge From a Fossil’s Taco Shell-Like Cover
description: An examination of an aquatic, shrimplike creature that lived half a billion years ago offers insight into how arthropods with mandibles became so common.
content: About 70 percent of the animals on Earth — including centipedes and bees, shrimp and crabs — are arthropods with mandibles, or pincerlike jaws. To understand how organisms with this anatomical feature became so diverse and successful over the last 500 million years, scientists looked inside the taco-like shell that protected an enigmatic creature that once swam in prehistoric seas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Mogg
title: Why Is My Hairstyle Giving Me a Headache?
description: The tension from tight box braids, ponytails and buns can cause pain and lead to hair loss, experts said.
content: Q: I wear hairstyles like box braids, cornrows and sleek ponytails, but sometimes they make my head hurt. Why does that happen? Should I be worried?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julius Krein
title: Republican Populists Are Responding to Something Real
description: Trump’s consolidated control of the G.O.P. has had the surprising effect of making its policies more, not less, unsettled.
content: Before last week’s Republican convention, Donald Trump seemed to be moving away from the populism that characterized his 2016 campaign. “This time around, the former president isn’t even pretending to stand up to corporate power,” Rogé Karma observed in The Atlantic. “He’s defending big business, cozying up to billionaires, and wooing C.E.O.s.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Genc
title: When All Else Fails, Blame the Dogs
description: Turkey’s four million stray dogs are inseparable from the idea of the country itself. But maybe not for much longer.
content: When I step out of my apartment in central Istanbul, dogs surround me. One lies dozing across the street. Another has sad eyes that are always looking for food, sympathy or both. They haunt city squares, they wait outside butchers and coffee shops. Some seem unhealthily overweight; others are skeletal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Travelers Delayed or Stuck by the CrowdStrike Outage: What Did Your Airline Provide?
description: The flight disruptions brought on by the global I.T. failure were deemed within the control of the airlines, meaning airlines have to reimburse passengers for meals, transportation and hotels. Did your carrier live up to the requirement?
content: If you were flying — or planned to fly — last week, your travel plans might have been snarled by an I.T. outage that kneecapped myriad industries and critical services worldwide. On Friday, July 19, alone, nearly 14 percent of the scheduled flights in the United States were canceled and 56 percent were delayed, according to Cirium, an aviation data company. In the days following, Delta Air Lines and other carriers continued to cancel and delay flights as they struggled with crews and planes out of position and the rebooking of thousands of passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: A.I. Can Write Poetry, but It Struggles With Math
description: A.I.’s math problem reflects how much the new technology is a break with computing’s past.
content: In the school year that ended recently, one class of learners stood out as a seeming puzzle. They are hard-working, improving and remarkably articulate. But curiously, these learners — artificially intelligent chatbots — often struggle with math.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Posner and Mark S. Zaid
title: The Government Has Failed America Since the Trump Shooting
description: Conspiracy theorists have been able to fill the information void with their own versions of the truth.
content: Those of us who have studied modern assassinations, including those of President John F. Kennedy and the civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., hoped the government had learned a lesson from its dismal public responses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Not Your Usual Secondhand Book Sale
description: Bibliophiles and film fans leafed through hundreds of books that once belonged to the eminent editor Robert Gottlieb.
content: Robert Gottlieb didn’t just edit books. He voraciously read and collected them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Vance Adjusts to His New Role, Aboard a Plane With His Name on It
description: As Donald Trump’s running mate, JD Vance has his own jet to fly him across the country. On Monday, he was still getting comfortable, both on the ground and in the air.
content: Senator JD Vance was unsure where to stand or where to put his hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Jonathan Swan, Luke Broadwater, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Harris Closes In on Nomination, and Secret Service Chief Berated
description: Plus, A.I. chatbots are flunking math.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: What Is the KHive?
description: Coconut emojis, Charli XCX mash-ups and a bunch of grainy lime green video clips. What to know about the latest iteration of the Kamala Harris fandom.
content: “You think you just fell out of a coconut tree?” Vice President Kamala Harris said last year at a White House event, chuckling as she quoted her mother. “You exist in the context of all in which you live and what came before you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Jim Rutenberg
title: Trump Tries to Flip the Script on Democracy After Biden’s Withdrawal
description: Donald J. Trump and his allies said President Biden’s primary voters were disenfranchised. Democrats noted Mr. Trump had once tried to toss out millions of ballots.
content: Ever since rioters stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, the Democratic Party has sought to claim the mantle of democracy, painting Donald J. Trump and his allies as extremists willing to deny the will of voters to cling to power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Under Fabric and Around Sculptures, Dancers Respond to Art
description: Jodi Melnick’s new work is performed throughout a gallery installation, while one by Annie-B Parson sprawls in a sculpture park.
content: Dance is notoriously impermanent. Perhaps as a reaction to that, more dancers have recently been making installations, viewable for days or weeks and only occasionally brought to life — “activated” is the usual term — with performances in situ.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Can Kamala Harris Finish Biden’s Climate Agenda?
description: If elected to the White House, Vice President Harris will face the challenge of implementing President Biden’s signature climate policies.
content: A lot has happened since we were last in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Maya C. Miller
title: Chuck Schumer and Hakeem Jeffries Back Harris After Hanging Back
description: Mr. Schumer and Mr. Jeffries, the two top Democrats in Congress, endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris as the party’s nominee after a process that played out “from the grass roots, bottom up.”
content: The top two Democrats in Congress, Senator Chuck Schumer and Representative Hakeem Jeffries, on Tuesday endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris for president, officially throwing their support behind her after she secured commitments from enough delegates to win the party’s nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why Some Donors Are Holding Back on Endorsing Harris (for Now)
description: Fear of being seen as circumventing an open nomination process is one reason that some backers have not yet publicly endorsed the vice president.
content: After just one full day of campaigning, Vice President Kamala Harris has a glide path to the Democratic presidential nomination. She has won endorsements from potential rivals and from powerful party figures like Representative Nancy Pelosi, the former speaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Finally, a Way Around Exorbitant Rental Car Surcharges for Tolls
description: Temporary toll passes, now free for those who rent cars at the Orlando airport in Florida, allow drivers to avoid charges for toll payment devices. Could this be a model for other destinations?
content: Tolls have long been the curse of rental car drivers, who often find their final bills inflated by per-day charges for access to automated toll payment devices provided by rental car companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 409, July 24, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and David A. Fahrenthold
title: Police Commander Provides More Details on Trump Rally Shooting
description: A Pennsylvania State Police colonel testifying before a House panel gave more answers about security for the rally than the Secret Service director had, but raised more questions.
content: Two days before a gunman wounded former President Trump in Butler, Pa., the Secret Service walked the site of the planned campaign rally with members of the Pennsylvania State Police, who had been pulled in for added security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: From Gowanus to Rhinebeck: ‘It’s a Whole Lifestyle Change.’
description: The two designers never planned to leave Brooklyn. But upstate New York beckoned.
content: When Charles Brill and Merrill Lyons bought land in upstate New York, they imagined building a weekend home there, an escape from their full-time life in Gowanus, Brooklyn. But that was before the pandemic made them rethink the way they lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Netanyahu Looks Like a Small Leader at a Historic Moment
description: Israel’s prime minister addresses Congress when the biggest chance to reshape the Middle East since Camp David in the 1970s is at hand.
content: When I think about Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s address on Wednesday to a joint meeting of Congress, the first thing that comes to mind is the famous dictum “There are decades where nothing happens, and there are weeks where decades happen.” This is one of those weeks for Israel, America and the Middle East. A decade is teed up to happen — or not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Veep’ Is Re-elected
description: After news broke that President Biden would endorse Vice President Kamala Harris as the Democratic nominee, the internet was rife with clips and memes from the show.
content: “Veep,” HBO’s merciless satire of Washington politics, went out with a gleeful whimper in 2019, a casualty of the Trump presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Judge Cannon and JD Vance Are on the Same Team
description: Precedent and the rule of law? Not if it gets in the way.
content: In the days since Judge Aileen Cannon issued her inexplicable 93-page dismissal of the classified-documents case against Donald Trump, I’ve been coming back to something JD Vance said on a podcast in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: This Fizzy Cocktail of a Movie Deserves a Second Chance
description: “Barb and Star Go to Vista Del Mar” has been woefully neglected. Maybe it was the culottes? But it will fill the “Barbie”-size hole in your summer.
content: Three years ago, deep in the bleak pandemic winter, we were blessed with a strange, movie-shaped gift. Starring and written by two of our most talented comedians, it was at once satirical, sincere, good-hearted and neon-colored. It took place mostly on a Florida beach. There were some dance numbers, a remix of “My Heart Will Go On,” a bunch of colorful sugar-bomb cocktails and an obsessive attention to culottes. The jokes came fast and furiously. A crab talked in a voice that sounded like Morgan Freeman. It was, in a word, perfect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Amid National Tension, a Man Placing Trump Signs Is Attacked in Michigan
description: An assailant ran over the 80-year-old man with an all-terrain vehicle, leaving him badly injured, law enforcement officials said, decrying the act of political violence.
content: An act of political violence in a small Michigan town left an 80-year-old man in critical condition over the weekend, local officials said. His assailant, who called the police to confess, later killed himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W. M. Akers
title: Her Films Defined a Gritty, Magical New York Moment
description: In the memoir “Desperately Seeking Something,” Susan Seidelman’s life is as full of twists, charm and happy endings as one of her iconic movies.
content: Susan Seidelman gave birth with the help of doulas named Siskel and Ebert. The director, best known for loving portrayals of gritty 1980s Manhattan, was in the final stages of a 28-hour labor when the film critics appeared on the hospital TV. They were discussing Seidelman’s newest film, the revenge comedy “She-Devil,” allowing her the unique discomfort of getting panned while an obstetrician prodded her cervix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Congress Leaders Agree to Form Task Force on Trump Assassination Attempt
description: The top Republican and Democrat in the House have struck a deal to form a bipartisan task force to lead congressional investigations into the attempted assassination of Donald J. Trump.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson and Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the House minority leader, have struck a deal to form a bipartisan task force to lead the congressional investigations into the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Allan
title: Kamala Harris the Prosecutor Has the Edge
description: She faces a moment different from when she ran for president in the 2020 cycle.
content: During Kamala Harris’s presidential primary campaign in 2019, she developed a reputation she has been unable to shake — that she’s a messenger in search of a message. This idea has also characterized her tenure as vice president and driven some Democrats’ concern about her potentially replacing President Biden at the top of the ticket. But it is outdated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Retires His Joe Biden Sunglasses
description: The “Late Show” host is putting his aviators on a shelf, now that the president has ended his re-election campaign.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Mayor Adams Dodges a City Council Threat by Making One of His Own
description: New York City voters will most likely be confronted in November with a referendum that may dilute the City Council’s power on public safety issues, thanks to a panel formed by the mayor.
content: Earlier this year, at a small meeting at City Hall between Mayor Eric Adams and leaders of an anti-crime group, two attendees complained about a New York City Council bill requiring the police to document more interactions with the public. They suggested that the mayor convene a charter revision commission to lessen the likelihood of similar legislation passing again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Transportation Department to Investigate Delta After Flight Delays
description: Pete Buttigieg, the transportation secretary, made the announcement after the airline suspended travel for unaccompanied minors.
content: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg said on Tuesday that his department had opened an investigation into Delta Air Lines after the tech outage last week disrupted flights worldwide, and the agency wanted to hear from travelers who said that the airline had not complied with passenger protection requirements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘Joker: Folie à Deux’ to Compete at Venice Film Festival
description: Pedro Almodóvar’s first English-language feature and new movies from Luca Guadagnino and Pablo Larraín will also debut at this year’s event.
content: “Joker: Folie à Deux,” Todd Phillips’s comic-book sequel starring Joaquin Phoenix and Lady Gaga, will compete for the Golden Lion at this year’s Venice International Film Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Lavitta’s Creole Serves Beignets and More in a 1940s Harlem Barbershop
description: Crawfish cakes with Creole aioli, a classic wild shrimp po’ boy and grits with red-eye lamb gravy are also on the menu.
content: A 1940s barbershop is being given new life as this Creole restaurant from Jimmy Thomas, who was schooled in Creole cuisine by his mother and grandmother while building his career at such places as Blackbird in Chicago, and in New Orleans and Paris. He named the intimate restaurant for his mother. His take on Creole cooking includes crawfish cakes with Creole aioli, a classic wild shrimp po’ boy, grits with red-eye lamb gravy and beignets. With a mere 32 seats, intimacy rules. An open kitchen and vintage touches enliven the space. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Ex-Military Police Officer Sentenced to Prison for Role in Capitol Riot
description: Gregory C. Yetman, the subject of a manhunt last fall, admitted to pepper-spraying law enforcement officers during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack.
content: A former Army National Guard police officer was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Tuesday after admitting that he pepper-sprayed law enforcement officers, while a mob of former President Donald J. Trump’s supporters stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Simon J. Levien
title: Harris Rallies Exuberant Democrats in Wisconsin: ‘The Baton Is in Our Hands’
description: Vice President Kamala Harris gave her first speech as the de facto Democratic nominee to a deafening crowd, keeping up her offensive against Donald Trump.
content: Delivering a jolt of enthusiasm to a party reeling from weeks of infighting, Vice President Kamala Harris rallied Democrats on Tuesday in Wisconsin and laid out a fierce argument against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Alexandra Stevenson and Thomas Fuller
title: Rival Palestinian Factions Project Unity, but Deep Divisions Remain
description: In a move brokered by China, Fatah and Hamas endorsed a unified government for the West Bank and Gaza, but Palestinians are skeptical that the two parties can put aside their differences.
content: The two main rival Palestinian factions, Fatah and Hamas, signed a joint statement in Beijing on Tuesday that endorsed, in concept, a temporary government for the Gaza Strip and the Israeli-occupied West Bank, in a grand show of unity brokered by China’s foreign ministry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Democrats Deserved a Contest, Not a Coronation
description: The party will pay the price for anointing Kamala Harris.
content: The last two times Democrats attempted to stage a coronation instead of a contest in choosing a presidential nominee, it did not go well. Not for Hillary Clinton in 2016. Not for Joe Biden this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Announces He Will Meet with Netanyahu on Friday at Mar-a-Lago
description: The pair, who were close allies, will meet after the Israeli prime minister gives a speech to Congress and meets with President Biden at the White House.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, who often calls himself the staunchest ally of Israel to ever sit in the Oval Office, will meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Friday in Palm Beach, Fla., Mr. Trump said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Inglesby, Anita Cicero and Marc Lipsitch
title: How to Reduce the Risk of a Catastrophic Lab Accident
description: What to know about a new U.S. policy.
content: It’s been about a century since viruses were recognized as causing devastating human diseases. Since then, scientists and public health experts have diligently tried to reduce the threats they pose by developing vaccines and treatments, improving ventilation and more.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Might Run With Kamala Harris?
description: Readers offer both Democrats and Republicans as well as a retired general as possibilities. Also: A quick race; Trump’s age; Biden and Netanyahu.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,131, Wednesday, July 24, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Nursing Home Owner Gets 3 Years’ Probation in Deadly Hurricane Evacuation
description: Bob Glynn Dean Jr. of Louisiana, who pleaded no contest to cruelty to the infirmed, Medicaid fraud and other criminal charges, will avoid prison time if he successfully completes probation.
content: A Louisiana nursing home owner who sent more than 800 residents to a squalid warehouse with what the authorities called poor sanitation and inadequate food supplies while they braced for Hurricane Ida in 2021 was sentenced on Monday to three years’ probation, despite prosecutors’ calls for prison time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Hydrothermal Explosion at Yellowstone Sends Tourists Racing for Safety
description: The explosion at Biscuit Basin, which sent a column of boiling water, mud and rock shooting into the sky on Tuesday, was caught in dramatic videos.
content: A hydrothermal explosion shot a towering column of boiling water, mud and rock into the air at Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming on Tuesday morning, destroying a section of boardwalk and sending dozens of tourists running for safety, officials said. No injuries were reported, according to the United States Geological Survey, but the area remained closed to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump’s New Rival May Bring Out His Harshest Instincts
description: After years planning to face President Biden, Donald J. Trump and his team will be campaigning against Kamala Harris. He has attacked female rivals and critics in brutal and personal terms.
content: Donald J. Trump and his political team spent nearly two years tailoring a campaign to defeat an old white male president who is conspicuously frail and who most Americans had told pollsters they doubted could handle another four-year term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: An Oscar Mayer Wienermobile Rolls Over. The ‘Hotdoggers’ Are OK.
description: No one was injured when the promotional car struck another vehicle and rolled over on a highway in Illinois, the police said.
content: You might expect to see litter, trash or even roadkill on the side of a highway. But a 3,600-pound hot dog? Just after 11 a.m. Monday, employees of Oscar Mayer were driving one of the company’s promotional Wienermobiles on an Illinois highway when the driver hit another car, lost control, overcorrected and rolled the vehicle on its side, the Illinois State Police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Secret Service Director Resigned
description: Also, Harris went on the offensive against Trump. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Kimberly Cheatle, the director of the Secret Service, announced her resignation today after acknowledging that her agency had failed to adequately protect Donald Trump from an attempted assassination earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Families Left Scrambling After Delta Bars Minors From Flying Alone in Wake of Outage
description: Pete Buttigieg said on Tuesday that the U.S. Department of Transportation had opened an investigation into Delta’s ongoing response to Friday’s global tech outage.
content: Scott Darling and his wife drove their 17-year-old son, Asher, to the San Jose airport on Sunday morning and saw him off at the check-in counter. They were back in their car and pulling out of the airport when they got a frantic call: Delta Air Lines wouldn’t let Asher check in because he didn’t have a parent accompanying him on the flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: What Comes Next for Robert Menendez?
description: The Senate Ethics Committee is starting to lay the groundwork to possibly expel the New Jersey lawmaker. He faces intensifying pressure to resign before that can happen.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll take a closer look at the trial of Senator Robert Menendez, who with his wife, Nadine Menendez, was accused of taking bribes of cash, gold and a Mercedes-Benz in a case that the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York said was about “shocking levels of corruption.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Army Sees No Link to Blast Exposure in Maine Gunman’s Mental Issues
description: Investigators found lapses in the handling of a troubled reservist who went on to kill 18 people, but they rejected suggestions that his Army work had damaged his brain.
content: An Army investigation into the October 2023 mass shooting committed by an Army Reserve soldier, Robert Card II, found that a number of missteps contributed to the Army’s inaction as Mr. Card’s mental health careened toward violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Rohter
title: John Mayall, Pioneer of British Blues, Is Dead at 90
description: He was best known not for his own playing or singing but for recruiting and polishing the talents of one gifted lead guitarist after another, starting with Eric Clapton.
content: John Mayall, the pioneering British bandleader whose mid-1960s blues ensembles served as incubators for some of the biggest stars of rock’s golden era, died on Monday. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Alexandra Stevenson
title: Multiple past attempts to broker unity have failed.
description: A joint statement supports the formation of a government of national consensus. But for many Palestinians, the gathering in the Chinese capital was nothing more than a performance bound for failure.
content: Fatah and Hamas signed a joint statement in Beijing on Tuesday in a grand show of unity, with the leaders of the rival Palestinian factions standing beside China’s foreign minister for a photo opportunity in an ornate hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: revue
description: This word has appeared in 52 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word revue has appeared in 52 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 24 in “Is New York Improv Back? I Went on a One-Week Binge to Find Out” by Jason Zinoman:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Michael Crowley
title: Harris’s Views on Israel Are in the Spotlight as Netanyahu Visits Washington
description: The vice president will be closely watched this week for signs of her approach to the war in Gaza should she win the White House in November.
content: In her first week as the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, Vice President Kamala Harris will confront the most politically divisive issue in U.S. foreign policy as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel pays an official visit to Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Why Katharine Graham’s Washington Home Has Sat Vacant for 22 Years
description: The home of the former Washington Post publisher was once a hub of power and comity. But after an “insane” renovation spat, its new owner is looking to sell.
content: President-elect John F. Kennedy was there for dinner the night before his inauguration. Years later, President-elect Ronald Reagan was there too. So were Truman Capote, Princess Diana, Supreme Court justices, cabinet members, diplomats, financiers and thousands more who came to a hub of bipartisan Washington power where guests dined, debated and often parted as friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Reality Show Contestant Apologizes After Eating Protected Bird
description: A contestant on the reality show “Race to Survive: New Zealand” killed and ate a weka during filming. The contestant, who said he was hungry, has apologized for “disrespecting New Zealand.”
content: Hunger was part of the challenge for contestants on the reality television show “Race to Survive: New Zealand.” As nine teams trekked, climbed and paddled their way through some of the country’s harshest terrain, they also had to forage and hunt for their own food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman, Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
title: The Gold Medalist Starring in India’s Olympic Dreams
description: Neeraj Chopra’s triumph in Tokyo inspired athletes across the world’s most populous nation. Now his country is chasing a bigger prize: a chance to host the Games for the first time.
content: The boy grew heavy on the milk, cream and butter of his grandmother’s doting. By age 13, Neeraj Chopra weighed nearly 190 pounds, making him one of the biggest boys in his tiny farming village. His father and uncles urged him to join a gym to lose weight. By chance, he saw a javelin being thrown and noticed that, in flight, it seemed to shimmy like a fish through water. He was smitten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Mark Zuckerberg Stumps for ‘Open Source’ A.I.
description: The chief executive of Meta said in an open letter that it was important that the technology was not controlled by a handful of giant companies — including his own.
content: For years, technologists have debated whether it is better for companies to keep the details of their computer code secret or share it with software developers around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Does Beyoncé Granting Kamala Harris Permission to Use Her Song Mean Something More?
description: Not quite a full-throated endorsement, but the use of the pop star’s song “Freedom” marked a moment.
content: The Beyoncé anthems returned to the campaign trail this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Top Japanese Gymnast Withdraws From Paris 2024 for Smoking and Drinking Alcohol
description: Shoko Miyata, the team’s captain, withdrew from the Games after an investigation by the country’s gymnastics board found she had violated its code of conduct.
content: Japan’s Olympic gymnastics team will head into the Paris Games this week without its captain, Shoko Miyata, after she withdrew from the team following an investigation that found she had violated the squad’s code of conduct by smoking and drinking alcohol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: In ‘Pre-Existing Condition,’ a Character Isn’t Defined by Abuse, or One Actress
description: Stars like Edie Falco and Deirdre O’Connell bring a communal quality to Marin Ireland’s play about the aftermath of domestic violence.
content: Most actors will tell you that when they take on a role, they want to own it. If it’s a classic or a play based on a movie, they like to say that they avoid watching earlier performances so they can go in free of preconceptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: How the Biden Campaign Transformed Into the Harris Campaign
description: Staff members inside and outside the room have described the past handful of hours as hectic, overwhelming and emotional.
content: After President Biden announced his departure on social media, it was somehow fitting that the call to flip the campaign to Vice President Kamala Harris was delivered over Slack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leanne Abraham, Helmuth Rosales, Elena Shao, Anjali Singhvi and Charlie Smart
title: How the Trump Rally Gunman Had an Edge Over the Countersnipers
description: The Times recreated, in 3-D, the lines of sight for three countersniper teams and the would-be assassin.
content: The Times recreated, in 3-D, the lines of sight for three countersniper teams and the would-be assassin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao and Martín González Gómez
title: Here Are the State Delegations That Endorsed Kamala Harris in the Days After Biden Withdrew
description: In a show of party unity, state delegations overwhelmingly endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris in the days after President Biden withdrew from the presidential race.
content: In a show of party unity, state delegations overwhelmingly endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris in the days after President Biden withdrew from the presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Albert Sun
title: See How Biden Lost Support in the Polls Before He Dropped Out
description: President Biden’s polling deficits grew in every single swing state between the debate and Sunday, when he exited the race.
content: President Biden’s polling deficits grew in every single swing state between the debate and Sunday, when he exited the race.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Senator Menendez’s Resignation Letter
description: Senator Robert Menendez announced in a letter to Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey that he would resign as of Aug. 20.
content: Senator Robert Menendez announced in a letter to Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey that he would resign as of Aug. 20.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tracking Typhoon Gaemi
description: See the likely path for Gaemi.
content: See the likely path for Gaemi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Nikolay Nikolov, Laura Salaberry, Christina Shaman, James Surdam, Farah Otero-Amad and Alexandra Ostasiewicz
title: What Kamala Harris’s Path to the White House Looks Like
description: Vice President Harris has begun a new concerted effort to reintroduce herself to the American electorate after President Biden endorsed her to lead the Democratic ticket. Zolan Kanno-Youngs, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains what this new path will look like.
content: Vice President Harris has begun a new concerted effort to reintroduce herself to the American electorate after President Biden endorsed her to lead the Democratic ticket. Zolan Kanno-Youngs, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains what this new path will look like.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kamala Harris Speaks at First Campaign Event
description: “It is my intention to go out and earn this nomination and to win,” the vice president said at her campaign headquarters in Delaware. President Biden called in to the event to express his support.
content: “It is my intention to go out and earn this nomination and to win,” the vice president said at her campaign headquarters in Delaware. President Biden called in to the event to express his support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Storyful
title: Large Wildfires Prompt Evacuations in Western Canada
description: There were more than 160 active wildfires in Alberta on Monday, with around 7,500 people under evacuation orders.
content: There were more than 160 active wildfires in Alberta on Monday, with around 7,500 people under evacuation orders.
source.name: The New York Times
